params.text:
• Understand a short and simple email
  • Recognise the main types of email
  • Identity emergencies

Reading

Understand Current Correspondence

Language in Action
Reading: Introduction

Ever feel overwhelmed by all those emails in your inbox? This module equips you with the skills to conquer your email world! 

Here's what you'll explore:

1. Understanding Emails: Learn strategies to understand the key points of any short and simple email.

  2. Email Types: Discover the different types of emails you might encounter, from requests to updates.

  3. Spotting Emergencies: Master the art of recognizing urgent emails that require immediate attention.
Understand A Short And Simple Email: Key Points

Emails can be like mini messages, but how do you crack the code and understand what they're all about? 

Here are some tips to become an email ninja:
Scan for Key Information:
• Just like a detective, look for clues! Focus on the sender's name (who sent it?), the subject line (what is it about?), and the first sentence (what's the main point?).
Identify Action Verbs:
• Verbs tell you what someone wants or needs. Look for words like "send," "reply," "meet," or "confirm" to understand what the email is asking of you.
Pay Attention to Context Clues:

• Sometimes, words and phrases around an unfamiliar word can help you guess its meaning.
    For example, if the email mentions a "meeting tomorrow," you can probably understand that "meeting" refers to a gathering of people.
Keep it Simple:
• Emails are usually written in a casual and direct way. Don't overcomplicate things - focus on the main ideas and what the sender needs from you.
Understand A Short And Simple Email - Forum & Quiz

You are on an online forum where people are discussing how to understand emails.
Please read the posts and answer the questions below:

choices.question:
Question 1 of 3: Micah says subject lines are helpful when understanding emails.
Why are subject lines useful?
answers:
They act like mini headlines summarizing the main idea of the email. 

They contain a long and detailed message preview.

They include information about when the email was sent.

choices.question:
Question 2 of 3: Bryan says verbs are like action heroes in emails.
What does Bryan mean by this?
answers:
Verbs tell you what the sender wants you to do (e.g., reply, confirm). 

Verbs are the most difficult words to understand in an email. 

Verbs describe the appearance of the sender.

choices.question:
Question 3 of 3: Anthony suggests that surrounding words can help understand unfamiliar words.
Why might this be helpful?
answers:
The surrounding words can provide clues about the meaning of the unknown word. 

You should focus only on the unfamiliar word and ignore the rest of the sentence. 

It's best to skip the sentence entirely if there's an unknown word.

params.text: Micah:
Bryan:
Micah: "Subject lines are lifesavers! They're like mini headlines that tell you the main idea of the email. Always check the subject line first to see what the email is about."
Bryan: "Verbs are like action heroes in emails! They tell you what the sender wants you to do. Look for words like 'reply,' 'meet,' or 'confirm' to understand what they need from you."

Anthony: "Don't get stuck on every unknown word! Sometimes, the words around a tricky word can help. For example, if it says 'meeting tomorrow,' you can probably guess 'meeting' means getting together to talk."
Anthony:

questions:
Subject: Meeting about Marketing *Plan*

Hi,

Just a quick *note* to remind you about our meeting tomorrow at *10* a.m to discuss the proposed marketing plan. Please *let* me *know* if you can't *make* it.

See you then, *Abigail*

metadata.title: Understand A Short And Simple Email - Fill in the Blanks

params.text: Recognise The Main Types Of Email: Key Points

Emails come in all shapes and sizes, but don't worry!

Here are some skills to help you recognize the main types:
Subject Line:
• The subject line is like a secret message revealing the email's purpose. Look for keywords that hint at the type of email, such as "Meeting Invitation" or "Order Confirmation."
Greeting & First Sentence:

• The opening can be a big giveaway! Greetings like "Hi [Name]" or "Dear Mr./Ms. [Last Name]" suggest a more formal email, while "Hey there" or "Just a quick note" might be informal. The first sentence often introduces the main point - is it a request, an update, or perhaps an invitation?
Body:

• Sometimes you need to investigate a little further. Quickly scan the email body for keywords or phrases that give clues about the type of email. For instance, "Please let me know if you can attend" suggests a request for your participation in something.
Closing & Signature:

• The closing can also offer hints. Formal emails might end with "Sincerely" or "Best regards," while informal ones might use "See you later" or "Thanks!" Finally, the sender's signature (e.g., John Smith, Marketing Manager) can indicate their role and the email's purpose (perhaps from the Marketing department).

answers.text: Emails asking for information about a product or service

params.text: Recognise The Main Types Of Email: Interactive video
Please watch the following video and answer the questions:
Recognise The Main Types Of Email - Forum & Quiz

You are on an online forum where people are discussing how they recognise different types of emails.
Please read the posts and answer the questions below:

choices.question:
Question 1 of 3: Abigail says the subject line can be a clue to the type of email.
What kind of subject line might indicate a meeting invitation?
answers:
"Meeting about [topic]" 

"Order Confirmation" 

"Hi Abigail, How are you?"

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: Micah says the beginning of an email can be helpful. How can the beginning help identify a formal email?
answers:
It might use a greeting like "Dear Ms. Jones." 

It will use a lot of difficult vocabulary. 

It will start with many exclamation points!!!

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: Bryan suggests looking at the closing and signature for clues. Why might the sender's title be helpful?
answers:
It can indicate the sender's department or role (e.g., Customer Service), giving a hint about the email's purpose.

It tells you the sender's favorite color. 

It contains a funny joke.

params.text: Abigail:
Micah:
Abigail: "The subject line is my first clue! If it says 'Meeting about [topic],' I know it's an invitation. But if it's 'Order Confirmation,' then it's about something I bought online."

Micah: "The beginning is important too! A formal email might say 'Dear Ms. Jones,' but an email from a friend might start with 'Hey Abigail!' The first sentence can also be a giveaway. Does it ask me to do something, or tell me news?"

Bryan: "Don't forget the end! Formal emails often say 'Sincerely,' but informal ones might be more casual, like 'Talk soon!' The sender's title can be a clue too. If it says 'Sarah, Customer Service,' I know it's probably about an order."
Bryan:
Identity Emergencies: Key Points

Not all emails are created equal! Sometimes, an email might be screaming "URGENT!"

Here are some detective skills to help you identify emergency emails:
Warning Signs in the Subject Line:
• Keep an eye out for all caps, exclamation points, or words like "URGENT," "HELP NEEDED," or "IMPORTANT." These are red flags that something might require immediate attention.
The Tone of the Email:
• Urgent emails often have a serious or stressed tone. Look for phrases like "We need this ASAP" (as soon as possible) or "This requires your immediate attention."
Request for Quick Action:
• Does the email ask you to reply or complete a task right away? Words like "immediately," "today," or "within the next hour" can signal urgency.
Sender & Context:
• Consider who sent the email and the situation. An email from your boss with "URGENT" in the subject line might require a faster response than one from a friend.
Identity Emergencies: Opinions & Exercise
Please listen to the following opinions and fill in the missing words:
Anthony:
Bryan:
Abigail:

params.textField: "All caps in the subject line are a big *giveaway* for me! If I see something like 'URGENT: REPLY NEEDED', I know it needs my attention *right* away. Also, if the email says 'We need this ASAP', that *usually* means 'as soon as possible', so I get on it *quickly*!"

params.textField: "The *tone* of the email can be a big clue too. If it sounds *stressed* or worried, like 'There's been a problem and we need your help!' then I know it's important. And if the email asks me to do something '*immediately*' or 'today,' that usually means it can't *wait*."

params.textField: "The sender can also be a tip-off. An email from my boss with an *exclamation* point in the subject line is probably more *urgent* than one from a friend. The situation *matters* too. If it's about something critical, like a deadline or a system outage, then it *likely* needs a fast response.""

choices.question:
Question 1 of 3: You receive an email from your friend with the subject line "Hey! Catching up tonight?" The email body asks if you're free to hang out later that evening.
What is the BEST way to respond to this email?
answers:
You can reply at your convenience - it doesn't seem urgent.

Respond immediately and let your friend know you can't wait. 

Mark the email as unread to come back to it later.

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: You see an email with the subject line in ALL CAPS: "URGENT!! NEED ORDER CONFIRMATION BY TODAY." The email is from a company you recently ordered something from. What should you do about this email?
answers:
Reply to the email as soon as possible and find your order confirmation information. 

Delete the email because you don't remember the order. 

Ignore the email for now and plan to deal with it later tonight.

choices.question:
Question 3 of 3: An email from your teacher has the subject line "Reminder: Essay Due Tomorrow." The email body mentions the essay is due at the beginning of class tomorrow.
How should you handle this email?
answers:
Make sure you have your completed essay ready to submit in class tomorrow. 

Respond to the teacher and explain you need more time to finish the essay. 

Open the email later to see what the essay topic is about.

params.text: What Would You Do? Quiz
Imagine you're checking your inbox and see these emails. Use your detective skills to decide what to do!
Module Summary Quiz
Choose the BEST answer for each question:

choices.question:
Question 1 of 6: You're skimming an email to find the main point quickly.
What is the BEST strategy to use?
answers:
Scan for the sender's name, subject line, and first sentence. 

Read every sentence carefully from beginning to end. 

Focus on difficult vocabulary and try to understand every word.

choices.question: Question 2 of 6: An email from your friend says: "Hey there! Let's meet for coffee tomorrow at 10 am. See you then!" What is the MOST LIKELY type of email this is?
answers:
An invitation to meet up with a friend. 

An email from a company about a recent purchase. 

A formal email from your teacher about an assignment.

choices.question: Question 3 of 6: You see an email with the subject line in ALL CAPS: "URGENT! REPLY NEEDED ASAP!" What does this suggest about the email?
answers:
It likely requires a quick response.

It's a friendly email from a colleague asking how your weekend was. 

It contains a lot of information that you need to read carefully.

choices.question: Question 4 of 6: When trying to understand the main idea of an email, it's helpful to ask yourself questions like "Who, What, When, Why". Why is this a good strategy?
answers:
It helps you gather clues about the purpose and content of the email. 

It helps you find all the difficult vocabulary in the email. 

It allows you to skip irrelevant details in the email.

choices.question:
Question 5 of 6: An email from your manager ends with "Best regards, Sarah Jones, Marketing Manager".
What can you potentially learn from the signature?
answers:
It gives you a hint about Sarah's role and department (Marketing). 

It tells you the date the email was sent. 

It lets you know how well Sarah knows you.

choices.question: Question 6 of 6: You receive an email with the subject line "Reminder: Project Meeting Today at 3 pm." What action might be most appropriate based on this email?
answers:
Review your notes and prepare for the project meeting at 3 pm. 

Delete the email because you already know about the meeting. 

Ignore the email for now and plan to read it later tonight.
